element_texts.text:
DOROTHY CANFIELD FISHER                                                 [1951]
                                                                                                                  ARLINGTON,  VERMONT                  January 26

Dear Mr. Conroy:

                        I'm really moved by your letter   - you seem to this ancient Vermonter still quite young (I hope you don't mind) so that I can hope your older "artless and unquestioning faith in America" which was like ?  artless and

unquestioning in ? beats, is beaten down and broken, will survive in the toughened, older - generation, dogged, deep-rooted  hope?, while as one gets older takes the flow[?] of faith (if you are fortunate.  My feeling is that we have our  fighting  chance to keep America living in the real meaning of the word - and a brave heart needs no more than a fighting chance to

2.)   go on with the struggle.  Do you remember the old Scotch ballad in which the chief of the clan is sore wounded, and falls, but shouts to his men to go on with the battlle,

               "I'll just lie down and bleed awhile, and then I'll rise to fight again,"

he calls.  Well, I hope that

                       in pencil [Jan. 26, 1951]

this is a time, for you, of "just lying down and bleeding awhile" _____________ and nothing more decisive.

    Thanks so much for the  pra..ni?  of Sam Patch.  You're good to remember me with it.

                            Faithfully and cordially your
                                    Dorothy Canfield Fisher

upside down DOROTHY CANFIELD FISHER Arlington, Vermont

haven't tried very hard.     Cal A. Fisk.

postmark DEARBORN, MICH. AUG 18 1950
August 18, 1950
Dear Yaddo Daddo,

 Your cards received and appreciated. We too are

taking a trip. Expect to visit Toronto, Niagara Falls, Buffalo,
Cleveland etc. Hope to be back by the time you are.

You never told me about the Rosewood Caskett. I'll be 

interested to hear of it.      CRF.

It is raining steadily tonight

HON. J.W. CONROY
Author, Critic, & Literary Pundit,
YADDO,  SARATOGA SPRINGS
NEW YORK.

Image of Linus - [from Charlie Brown cartoon] saying I Love Mankind, It's PEOPLE I can't stand!!
603 Highland Ave.
Oak Park, ILL. 60304
March 26th, 1969
Dear Jack,

I suppose that because of your aged and decrepit condition you have been straining your brain since

the Christmas holidays to concoct the review of underline Illinois River Hokey-pokey /underline
which appeared in the March 16th issue of "Book Week" of the Sun Times. Otherwise I would have received
an answer to my note which accompanied the Xmas card sent you at that time.

 Are you on the mailing list and do you get World Progress, The Standard Quarterly Review? It stinks. I went

in and saw Mr. W. H. Ward, Sr. a few months ago. He is in bad shape; can hardly see, is very thin and quite
shaky. As I wrote you, I am leading

image of Snoopy - [from Charlie Brown cartoon] saying Life is Full of Rude Awakenings.

a life of underline Leisure /underline. Have read a couple of books: underline Man

and Dolphin /underline by J.C. Chilly M.D., and underline The Lawyers /underline
by Martin Mayer. I also keep up with Saturday Review and The New Yorker.

Our son Robert is a first Lieutenant of Combat engineers. He is married and has two daughters.

He is getting out of the service on May 1st. He has had a number of jobs offered him and is
deciding which one. We are phoning him Tuesday evening (tomorrow) to find out what he
decides. One is with the National Bank of Detroit at $10,000 per annum. The other is with the
O'Neill Company of Akron, Ohio, a large department store chain affiliated with the May
Company department stores. Bob is stationed at Fort Belvoire, Virginia.  Let me hear from you.

  Cal.

603 Highland Ave.
Oak Park, ILL 60304
Sept., 16th, 1969
Dear Jack,

I am too lazy to get out the typewriter, please excuse the cursory writing. Reading your newest review last week

in Book Week of the Sun Times, and the arrival today of World Progress, The Standard Quarterly Review
reminded me that I am as slothful as is the getting our of that publication. The issue received is the underline
Summer /underline one that should have be mailed in July.  Your April letter was refreshing. Glad to learn that
you manage to grab off some dollars here and there; I hope you earn them.  I certainly do remember the grandsons;
always thought you were mean to call the one "Jughead".

 Saw Win Stracker's picture in the paper; he too is getting old. Remember when I got him out to the Third Unitarian

Church and he had them all singing "I'll be a Methodist till I die."  I [resume you saw the typo in your review of
underline The Coming of the Rain. /underline Last paragraph, first word: Through instead of Though. Your
review of Missouri Bittersweet was missed by me.

 Frances and I spent a week in Florida in the latter part of August. Went down to visit her sister in Fort Lauderdale.

in pencil [Sep. 16, 1969]
2)

On arrival by Delta airlines, found her in the Emergency department of Holy Cross Hospital. She had passed out

in her apartment; her daughter found her there. Te regular doctor was on vacation; his substitute made a big deal
of it. Got her out of there in three days; took her home (to her daughter's). she is now much better than she had
been previously.   As for Florida, they can have it. It's not for me. I seem to be running out of steam. Take care
of yourself and your wife. Fran and I send our best thoughts to you and yours.

 Your friend,  Cal. R. Fisk

P.S. Lolligagged around and didn't mail this. Found the enclosed in the Daily News; thought you might enjoy it.

  CRF

March 28th, 1970
Dear Jack,

 On the first of this month, I read your review of underline New Masses /underline in the Sun Times.

Intended to drop you a line, but put it off from day to day. More recently I read excerpts from Stud Terkel's
underline When Times Were Really Hard /underline which are in the April issue of the Atlantic
Monthly. I'd like to read the entire book, but I'm too stingy to buy it. did I write you that I had an interesting
note from don Russell at Xmas time? He mentioned that he had been down to Moberly. As you may have
read, we had a dandy snow storm here. It began late Wednesday as rain. Then

Page 2

it turned to snow. All night the wind blew and howled. O'Hare got some 16 inches. Here in Oak Park

we got six or seven inches. Yesterday the sun came out in the afternoon. The trees were covered with
snow and ice. As it warmed up, the ice fell from the trees. Driving along, the ice would fall and hit the
top of the car. The sound was frightening, but the ice did no apparent damage. A great many branches
of the trees broke off during the night and littered the streets.

 The hell of it is that the weather men think we may get another one by Sunday.
 I now have six grandchildren. My older son, Stephen, has four. He is a mechanic with Trans. Continental

Lines (Trucking). He had one daughter and two sons,

Page 3
and thought he was through. Then last year he and his wife surprised themselves and had another son Jimmy).

 Robert (my younger son) has two little girls, Lisa who will be three on June 5 and Julia who will be two

in September. Bob is in the department of methods and Procurement of the National Bank of Detroit. (14th
largest bank in the U.S.). He is making $12,000 a year there plus his remuneration from the Army Reserves. 
He was a first lieutenant in the Army Combat Engineers, and received a Commendation Medal for his work
as Director of Instruction, Plans and Program Division, U.S. Army Engineers School.

 However, Bob is planning to go back to school and get a Masters degree. He has been accepted for a teaching

Page 4

 fellowship at Northern Illinois University. He also is communicating with the University of Colorado. Had

not heard from them finally last week. His wife prefers Colorado (they both were there one summer). We
prefer Northern Illinois, as that is closer.

 I have often wished you were nearer at hand. I have an idea for a novel, but don't feel up to it alone.
 Received the Winter Quarterly last week - six weeks late and it is mighty poor.
Happy Easter      Yours   Cal R. Fisk

Oak Park, Illinois
August 23rd, 1973
Sage Jack Conroy:

Illustrious Sir, a very peculiar happening occurred last Saturday: When I awoke in the morning,

the first thing I thought of was that I should write to you. I also was thinking about Don Russell
telling me about his visit with you a year or so ago.

 We have had my wife's niece and her husband visiting with us this month. They live in Fort

Lauderdale. They are originally from this area. Their names are Joe and Vera Hunt. Joe's brother
lives in Antioch, ILL. He is a widower (plenty of money as has Joe). So Joe is up there visiting
him, and Vera is here with us. Vera and Frances have been going here and there together. At last
here is the peculiar happening. On that same Saturday mentioned before, they brought with them in
the late afternoon a copy of the Chicago Daily News. There in the "Panorama" section is the article
about "The Sage of Moberly".  So now I am writing the letter which I probably would have written
anyhow. As to the article in the News, I think it could have been better.   Perhaps you'd like to know
something about what has been happening to me. Well, I was doing very well

Conroy - 2
until a short time ago. I celebrated my 77th birthday on July 6th and was feeling great. Soon afterward, I was
overtaken by a failure of some older people: leaking urine. It is a hell of a problem. I spent several days and nights
in Hines Veterans Hospital. They Xrayed me, examined my prostate, irrigated my bladder (twice) and that was
painful. Now I home, taking an antibiotic and another small bitter pill four times per day. I believe I am getting
better.  We plan to have a few improvements made to the basement of our house and sell it. We do have full electric
air conditioning. The reason for selling is that our colored brethren are moving closer and closer. Also, we are
getting to the point where household chores are too much.   Our son, Robert, served in the Army as an officer, made
First Lieutenant and received the Army Commendation Medal. He now is a Captain in the Reserves. He is married,
has a charming wife, owns an attractive house in DeKalb and is working on his Ph.D. at night. During the day he is a 
painting contractor and is making plenty of money - If things turn out right, we may be s topping to see you at some
future time.   My best regards to your wife and you.

 Cal. R. Fisk  603 Highland Ave, Oak Park, IL 60304

Dec. 6, 1964
Dear Mr. Pasternak, I mean Dilgas, I mean Conroy:

 All this esopian [sic: aesopian] gobbledegook I read in your P.M., no I mean Showcase must

be brainwashing.

 However, I've got it straight now. Its still a publication of the old Lecher Marshall

Fielding jr. and its still the old party line, untill [sic] you are told what the new party
line is, whether the publication be P.M. or Showcase and the Gobbledegooker, Conroy,
or some other stooge.

 That was a marvelous syllogism you had in your Nov. 22, 1964 minor classic, Latvia,

Estonia, Lithuania, Roumaina [sic], Bulgaria, Hungary

Czechoslovakia, Poland, Albania, Red China, Jugo-Slavia [sic] are under Communist Red army control,
therefore in Communist eyes and their stooges, legal. They tried to do this in Spain therefore in their
brainwashed glaze, this was legal, and because the Spanish people led by Franco prevented it, all the
doctrinaire reptiles come out from under their rocks and hiss at the Gereralissimo.

 Just as they will resume their rattling at Chiang Kai Shek, like the subservient little stooges they are

when their Kremlin masters find out whether Jackoff, Goofoff, Knockoff, or Shoveoff is the new
temporary God for all the truckling sychophants [sic] to get

down before, and close themselves even more, if that is possible for such degradates.

 That was a marvelous fable Feiffer had on the KGB in your cozy little pit Nov. 22 or is

it the MVD, or the Goy Poy Ooh or the Cheks, or Phew, Is it

the comrade temerious [sic] in twitting the Soviet Secret Police. Oh but I forgot, there is the
thaw since the demise of Uncle Joe, that you wrote about so learnedly, [ableitly esopianly-sic] 
in P.M., er I mean showcase.

 If he wrote that in the benighted U.S. about the F.B.I. he'd be in trouble wouldn't he? Comrade! 
     T. Flanagan  613 N. Wells Chicago, ILL.

KINNARA DISTRIBUTORS
6821 S. Crandon Avenue
Chicago, Illinois 60649
HY3-6110   776-0700

May 23, 1971

Dear Jack:

  Never thought I'd soon be forced to be a giant operator in business,

did you?

 The worm? is turning (I hope)!
Best to you both!   Luise & Ray Flerlage

427 E. 8th St.
Mich. City, Ind.
Aug 4, 1963
Mr. Jack Conroy
Columbia College
207 S. Wabash Ave.
Chicago, Illinois

Dear Sir:
 Today, I read the article "Write Fini? to Nothing", in the Chicago Tribune Magazine section. It was

most interesting to me because I had just completed my work with two Creative Writing groups.

 Both groups wrote and produced their own plays during the six weeks summer session in the

Elementary School.

 We also published the school newspaper and wrote original stories and poems.
 Could you please inform me as to the nature of the courses

in pencil [no date] Flint, Mary G.  [1963 - from previous page]

you offer? Are any of the courses set up for use at the elementary level?
 I would really be very happy to receive any information that you have

available.

 when is your next rouse in Creative Writing going to start?
   Thank you most kindly.    Most respectfully,     Mary G. Flint

The danger of dining with a literary an is that, while the desire to write may be caught,

in the same way that one catches a cold from another person, the underline ability /underline
to write does not seem to be catching.

 at any rate, the attached is the result of my muchly appreciated visit. I obtained amusement in

writing it (on your typewriter) and that surely is enough. Please consign to the waste basket when
(or IF) read.    D.F.
[[h/w]  Many thanks for the book - I would like you to write a few words in it - I can get it later.   D.F.

Jack!

Don't pay the 6 c again.  I paid the postman
  D.F.

Trust you & Madame Q & Company are all well. What think of Harper on Harper?
Where are (is) you memoirs??      Mike*   in pencil [1970?]

card image of woman in Victorian dress

 this is the kind what sent our kind into exile!

.........

 Happy $mas!     M&M

on side  The Micks & the Puritan WASPS do have something in common!

27 March 1972
Dear Jack,

 I do not believe that there was any official publication date. The SFChron reviewed it

9 March, so let's say that was the date. Shitty review too. Plum stupid. You'll give me hell,
I'm sure, but it'll be smart hell, and that's all I ask. Looking more and more like we'll
be driving through this summer. Save some greens.      best,     Mike*

I'll look up the Mo. magazine - but we need the underline whole /underline autobiog

* Folsom, according to pages further on

18 Jan 73

Jack -    Marcia says many thanks
   Mike  Folsom

Michael Folsom
biogr. of Mike Gold

 Dec. 20, 1975

Dec '75
Dear Jack & Gladys - -

 Well, I finally got canned by MIT good and proper after 9 [count 'em] years, but we are flourishing

none the less. Might even get another job someday. Gonna write some for a while.

 Raphael & Janie [Jamie?]   (goin' swimmin') join us in wishing good cheer to the Jack of Moberly
     M&M image of heart with arrow through it

Mrs. Clinton Foster
841 West Coates
Moberly, Missouri

Dear Gladys & Jack:
 While my little demon is sleeping better write you a note.
 I finished Paul's? book & Clint is reading it now. I was shocked to think such things

could happen to him. No wonder he looks like he does.

 When we come up I want Clinton to meet him. Clint is all set on coming up this June.
 Did you send Dippy a copy? Guess you don't know what to do with all those empty

rooms now that he & Tom both are gone.

Did you have a nice time at the party you wrote me about?
  Thanks again for seeing I got a book & taking time out to write to us.
      Love,   Mary, Clinton & Jim

What's with you? Hope you are O.K. and having a little fun.

 I am going to be grandma again. Everyone is happy but Mandy. Says she is going to leave home.

I do hope its a boy and looks just like Clint.

 Durie spend the day with them. I have my tree up and all the presents under it, but am not far

along with my cards -     See you soon!

in pencil Foster, Mary [1984]

Tuesday

Dear Jack,

As promised, I will keep in touch. As you know I don't come to Moberly very much,

a couple or three times a year.

 I enjoyed our visit so much and do wish we could have bar? to-gether again. Be 

sure and eat plenty- people living along sometimes neglect to do so. I cook a lot for
myself as I remember when I was living at home I didn't have enough.

I love my job at the hospital and a nurse that came with blood mobile to Moberly called

and wants me to help her. I did that in Moberly for so long - if you remember.

 I went to Fulton Sun, to play cards. We started at 3 in the afternoon

and played all night. Got home at 7 am. Monday. Needless to say Monday was a lost day,
but I slept good last night.

 I am going to town and mail my letters and do some other things.     Take care and remember

if you need me let me know. Don't usually hear from Stella so fast, but she wrote me that she was
there and thought she would see me. She would have if she had let me know.

  Love ya!    Mary

Feb 6th 1956
Dear Jack & Gladys:

 Our books came a few min. ago. I am so proud of them & my bottle - you didn't forget.
 I have the bottle & the books on the mantel in the bedroom. I have ever heard from the

book of the month club yet. Maybe I am too impatient.

 We are sending the .89 for postage & for you to write to me

again. The other dollar is for you Aunt Gladys to buy more mysteries.

 I would like to have Grace & Franks address, because I would like to

send them a little something a little later on.

 Are the kids home yet? Now is a wonderful time to be in Florida. Its rainy

& sleeting here.   I can see you now Jack, spending saturday boxing

up the books & walking to the post office. We underline do /underline
appreciate it too.      Love,  Mary, Clint & Jim
P.S. We had spegetti? yesterday. I found some Mace, but couldn't get anise.

in pencil  Frazier, Forrest
October 3rd - 1955
919 Dunbar,
Excelsior Springs,
Missouri

Dear Jack:
 I had a note from Jo Driskell, in which she mentioned sending me a clipping about Fred

Harrison being in the hospital with heart trouble, and that the clipping contained his
address. I didn't receive the item she mentioned so don't know much about how, or where
he is. Could you let me know, as I would like to drop him a note? I never did know his
Moberly address.

 Jo also said Dot Wisdom told her you and Gladys had been in Moberly on a short visit.

I wish I could have seen you, and that you could have come on here to visit me. I am
not sure

2
whether I wrote and told you where I was, or not. At least, I intended to do so, but I
have so darn little time these days. A twelve hour day - seven days a week doesn't
leave much time to carry out good intentions.

 Is Nelson Algren out in Hollywood working on "The Man with The Golden Arm"?

It should make a terrific movie, but I read an article in the K.C. Star the other day,
saying it would not be released because it dealt with narcotics? Imagine! What is the
world coming to. It seems that freedom of any kind is a thing of the past.

 Jack, isn't the Howard Rushmore who disappeared, and who had a wife jump in the

East river in N.Y.C., the boy who used to visit you in Moberly. Didn't he work in the

3
brick yard at Mexico, and contribute occasionally to the "Anvil". Maybe I am wrong, but
it seems the name is the same.

 I hope you and Gladys will come to visit me when you can. I don't have any time off, except a few

hours at night, but you can have the house to rest in to your heart's content.

 Let me know something about Fred - also, how - also, how you are faring.
    Best, your friend,   Forrest

If I did send you my old address here, please note that I am now at 919 Dunbar.
Forgive the messy letter, but I don't have time to do better now.

Dec. 12th
Dear Jack:

 I will write a few lines now, and try to get more off to you later. I was wondering if you

were moved. I knew you had partially moved, but thought maybe you had just brought your books on ahead.
I hope you have a better place for them than I have for mine. My things have just been piled up here for the
past five years, and I don't know where anything is. I know you are glad to get it over with.

 It was good news to hear that you are going

2
to do an autobiography. That should be a very important book, and should make money too.

 I hope you will be able to read this hasty writing. My typewriter is on the bum, and I

really need it bad.   I will try to write more soon.

  Best to you and Gladys,     As ever,    Forrest

Contest play - full length - Life of Li..? between 1815-1833
South Western Indiana Civic Assoc.

Ernest Owen
Indianapolis, Ind.

To Jack & the family,

 best wishes

printed May peace and serenity adorn the earth /printed

 Lew Fried

P.S. Just read your "Memories of Arna Bontemps" -

a fine and heartfelt endorsement?
 what's happening to underline Tropic Death? /underline

KENT STATE UNIVERSITY
Kent, Ohio 44242
Department of English
(216) 672-2676

27 Sept

Dear Jack

- I opened the enclosed letter but it was addressed to someone else - so I assume you got your

wires crossed - in haste.

 By accident, I read the first few lines. Please accept my deepest condolence & sympathy about

Margaret Jean.  Best regards to your wife.       Respectfully,    Lew Fried

KENT STATE UNIVERSITY
Kent Ohio 44242
Department of English
(216) 672-2676

8 July 77

Dear Jack,

 What can I say? Thanks so much for underline American Hunger! /underline

Enclosed are (1) your review of same and (2) a book I helped put together about
Jacob Riis.     The best,   Lew

THURSDAY  11 am.
Dear Jack -

 your PARCEL just arrived at St. Paul THANKS MUCH - Letter

from Redding indicates very favorable response for IRVINE, CAL -
re: your Lecture Tour - we have 4 plus & 1 negative - plus a few underline Non /underline-responses -

 I shall take your book to PAT ELLIS today on her 27 birthday -
 I get repeatedly discouraged - the B.S. progressive state of MINN - just ruled against a discrimination suit

brought by Black PARENTS against the

PoLice of MPLS -

I know the MPLS police are brutal - true WASPS in the worst sense of the word -
 Enclosed please find check - IF I owe you more (which I probably do) please advice -
 As soon as I return to S.D. I shall send you postage - 4 weeks in the Mid-west will wipe out -

J.P. Morgan - poor Guy -

 I board plane to S.D. SAT. Hope to see you in Sept.  please write.
Peace - Good health -  IRV. SYLVA

Regards to MRS. C -

We Received 2 copies of Studs Terkel new book for Gifts -

It is "Hot property" all over US - He appears on all TV shows - & Big Book Stores -

in pencil [1974]
image of [Richard Nixon] Watergateland, U.S.A.
Would You Buy A Used Country From This Man?
NO MORE LIES!

 SUNDAY

Dear Jack -

 Thanks for introducing us to Bob & Mary Redding & children - Sylva & I were becoming

bored with the great climate & poor intellectual atmosphere in may [many?] parts of SO. CAL -
They are fine people -

 Did you see the Latest Book re John Dos PASSOS? edited by Townsend Ludington - "14th Chronicle

a Fine Excerpt is in "Intellectual DIGEST" DEC. 1973 - Interesting photos EDMUND WILSON -
SACCO-VANZETTI rally 1927, E.E. Cummings - Hemingway, Malcolm Cowley, Sherwood Anderson, 
John Howard Lawson - letters to Upton SINCLAIR, F. Scott Fitzgerald; - see INTELLECTUAL DIGEST
- Dec. 1973

 I HAVE the issue of the North County ANVIL in which your fine article appears -
 Reddings & FRIEDMANS are cooking up a plot to bring you here for a talk

or series of TALKS - MRS. ConRoy is most welcome, if we can swing it -

 The problem is SAN DIEGO STATE U has Little $$ for convocations et al - If my

older son were pres of the STUDENT council - you would be here FIRST CLASS with
a check to your favorite charity -

 Do you know any NAME contacts at Nevada - Arizona colleges & other CALIF "Trade" 

schools - we would take the initiative to handle the matter if you know some other names &
addresses & forward to US - IF you are interested -

 OBVIOUSLY you NEED TRANSpoRTATION, SAUCE, Good SHELTER, FINE FOOD,

in ADDITION How Much Loot would you require?

 Your appearance at DULUTH-SUPERIOR is still well remembered - I get letters about it -

Justin KAPLAN the biographer of CLEMENS, is due with a book on LINCOLN

STEFFENS - you probably are up on this Literary gossip.

 Since I just had my 60th birthday just thinking of the TITANS of the 20s & 30s fills me with

nostalgia - your article on the OLD ANVIL has the same effect -

 A FATS WALLER record can haunt me for hours - Even old recordings of CHICAGO REP.

group - But old Artie Shaw who legally copulated with every HOT Hollywood star in the
THIRTIES says to watch out for Nostalgia - our generation burned SACCO-VANZETTI
and taught the kids how to till "gooks"

 I must plead "NOT GUILTY" I was related by a covenant to Ethel Rosenberg & her husband,

Julius. I think I can get you

off the "hook".

Tuesday.

Let me know how a TRIP to REAGAN-LAND & the U.S. NAVY "grabs" you.
I can arrange a destroyer ?nt with a 21 gun salute -

 Suggest anytime from OCT 1 to THANKSGIVING or early DEC.
Best wishes      Sylva & Irv.

in pencil [1974]
SAT. 8 A.M.
SKOKIE, ILL.

Dear Jack - THANKS For Letter & Book. PARTICULARLY moved

by your introduction to MIDLAND HUMOR & the issue of NEW LETTERS -
I shall have to look at PANORAMA If you can XEROX or have a copy to Lend
please forward -

 Kindly send one copy Any place But HERE -
 Your letters & writings bring out the Nostalgia - I recall MAX SIEGER from CARSON

PIRIE Book Sept 1935 - I remember the old BIBLE SALESLADY who was proper & a
friend of CARL HAMMERSMARK - The Latter was once associated with the Methodist
publishing co -

 I shall spend with Leo HERTZEL Monday NITE -  send me a few FLyERS re underline 

WRITERS IN REVOLT /underline to DULUTH.  I shall be in MINN - to SAT. JUNE 8.

The Black INTELLECTUALS ARE ON A KICK about Language  I Think the term M-F-

is a MO. barbarism picked up by the Blacks in St. Louis about 1920s & then "copyrighted"
by Negroes - Like Jews picked up the delicacies of LITHUANIA, POLAND, Russia,
Bohemia et al - Made them "Kosher" in ritual & figurative sense & now it is known a
YIDDISH cooking -

FRIDAY 7 A.M.

Dear Gladys & Jack -

 THANKS MUCH For "FOOLKiLLer" the repat on H.H. Lewis was very interesting - I forgot my

ukelele - "Patty Hearst" is a good ballot - The Lyrics to the "president's MAN" is better -

IF you have an extra copy send same to EARL & ELDRA CARNEY - 415 N. BATTIN, WITCHITA

KA [sic] - 67208 - They are old friends of the UNHOLY TRINITY - Welker H, Emil Mortel & IRV. F-
He is a native of MO, his wife - a descendant of LAWRENCE, KANS -rostabout's [sic] - her DAD
insisted that the JAMEs BROS. were holier than

Moses, Abraham & the Holy Father - He went straight & wound up at the U of ILL GRAD School
in the early 30s & then was an underpai & editor at RAND McNALLY Chicago - AFTER WWII
he went back to INDEPENDENCE Mo & wound up in WICHITA. good people - They Fought
SEN. Dole before it was Fashionable -

 Mortell was Lucky - Good sons & better wife - Recovered from tricky surgery - He was afraid

I went "soft" residing on underline ZION /underline St. - Hope PAUL BARTLETT Looks
us up - need a shot in the ARM - Ann ROZAHNSKY never returned call - She may be Looking

for a Rich retired semi disabled Jew? or a  VIriLe young ALIEN
Mexico -    Why in the hell doesn't Lew Fried send me a middle-aged SYRIAN
between 14 & 40 to bring detente among Semites -

 Two years ago Congress over rode FORD'S veto to increase GI BILL benefits -

Actually Ford was one of the worst Pres. in our 200 year history - A Gentleman
bastard & Arch reactionary -

 Carter may be called Jimmy, but not James - I predict by Passover - we will be

calling him shit-head.

Stay well - Too many of my friends are getting ill & expiring -
 Lay off SALT, FAT - drink dry wine - & do not watch TV.
   peace & Good Health     SyLva & IRV -

Dear Jack & GLADyS

 Glad to get your letter dated Norwegian Flag day - May 17 - 

Keep me posted on underline Jack ConRoy Reader - /underline - you certainly 
got good info from SUN TIMES - I am sure that way readers went to book stores Looking
for your book - I wrote friends in Chicago re Stephen Wade - who also got good
reviews - I talked to Cloquet Librarian re: your books - MINN has good public Libraries -
even in the hick towns - HIGH Literacy rates & tradition. Sinclair Lewis - Meridel Le Seur &
taxes from IRON MINES - paper Mills.

 Henderson & Mortel are poor correspondents. the former is perennially young

Good health - works full time and quasi-celibate ie a confirmed bachelor -

 Mortel is not well - but gets faithful attention from wife & sons -
 Please be sure to keep me posted re: book - let me know if Stephen Wade

is coming to MPLS.     Love to Gladys     SyLVA & IRV
Stay Well - peace   do not trust peanut vendors, CIA men, & other sooth-sayers -   IRV -

Tuesday  Bastille Day
Dear Jack & Frau

 Saw this call in N.Y. "ViLLage Voice" - Reminds

me of old days - MaLcolm Cowley - you - Hicks, Gold
Isidore Schneider, Joe Freeman, et al - Today - NAT HENTOFF
& Barbara Garson come close to the old gang - Terkel keeps going
strong from our generation -

 Mortel is not doing too well - I personally visited him last month

His wife & young son are very supportive - He had a stroke - has
Parkinsons- & is in a wheel chair - His mind & speech are clear - 
memory good - he does a lot of writing & reading.

 Like Ole Man RIVer - Henderson keeps

in pencil [July 1981]
going - working - chasing quail - He was terribly "shook up" when his Mother died - 103 -
She was a great lady -

 Let me know how you and Mrs. C are faring - Univ. - WISC at superior is not doing well -

losing students & teachers. Univ MINN at DuLuth going very strong.

 Economy cuts - Reagan & Local Reaganites are hitting schools - Libraries et al -

cutting funds, personnel etc. - DULUth built a gorgeous Library - but Like an Egyptian
Temple - closed 50% of the time - reduced staff & appropriation for books - Retirees in
schools & Libraries not being replaced

Cutting down "Fads & Frills". Speech - debate theatre - but not hockey -

shades of PASTEUR Semmelweis, Sabin - SACK - Reducing child immunization
& Health care for indigent aged - putting Jonathan Swift satire to test - Reduce 
starvation by encouraging the poor & elderly to eat each other.

 STAy Well   SyLVA & IRV

If ALGREN had not moved to Cuckoo Land he would be alive

 Incidentally I was glad to get out of L.A. - NATE West certainly understood that

Locust Land - "A pLace to die."

Monday 8 A.M.

Dear Jack -

 I have been careless with my correspondence  - How are you? The world becomes screwier

I frequently think it is most difficult for a FICTION WRITER,  How can a guy be more
imaginative than BUTZ, NIXON, FORD, SIMON?, HALDEMAN, ERLICHMAN,
MITCHELL & sundry other scoundrels? IMAGINE the ardesty of cutting down Social
Security, Food stamps, Vets Benefits while AT&T, SUGAR TRUST, OIL industry

are cleaning up -

Reagan now writes a column & pontificates on radio - I am constantly amazed

at the stupendous ignorance, deceit & tireny [sic] of the boys in power -

 There is no place to to to escape from idiocy - I MAy try booze - or downers or

uppers or sex - or PEYOTE. it becomes comprehensible that the kids drop out -

 WRITE - what is new?   Best Wishes - PEACE  Good HEALTH    SYLVA & IRV  -

Friday  Noon
Dear Jack -

  Thanks for your letter & pornographic enclosures - I have not moved -

telephone is in SYLVA'S name - I phoned Amelie & we had a Long talk -
Gave her my phone no., address - et al -

 China is the big current interest - I am for MAINLAND CHINESE 99%

but I get frightened when the moderately affluent UNITARIANS start
Traveling there -

 Congrats on your doctor's degree - Algren has been getting ridiculous

PR. lately - I fail to see why his going to PATERSON, N.J.

merits so much ink -

 Keep in touch re your publishings et al - I do push your talents & publications -
 Have not seen Bob Redding in 2 Months - have not seen Mary in 8 Months -

They are busy -

 You should visit us with Gladys - we do have room -
 SALZMAN is highly regarded -     Keep writing -   IRV
